The Educational Sciences major is offered by the Berkeley School of Education (BSE). The Educational Sciences major explores the field of education via academic inquiry and direct engagement with schools, families, and local and global communities. Through multidisciplinary training and participatory practices in school-based and community contexts, students will come to understand learning inside and outside of official institutions and will learn how to critically analyze current issues in education. The role of digital technologies in a networked world, and their capacity to elide educational time and space, will be an object of study. 


There are no lower division major requirements available for articulation.

Educational Sciences is offered through the Berkeley School of Education. However, transfer students who are interested in declaring the Educational Sciences major must initially apply to the College of Letters & Science, with Educational Sciences listed as their intended major. After students have completed one term at UC Berkeley, and have met the eligibility requirements for declaring the Educational Sciences major, they may declare this major. 


IMPORTANT information for students applying for admission to L&S for the fall 2025 application cycle and beyond


Completion of Essential Skills requirements (Reading & Composition, Quantitative Reasoning, and Foreign Language) or


Cal-GETC/IGETC will no longer be a requirement for admission; however, completion of either is strongly recommended prior

to enrollment at UC Berkeley to ensure timely degree progress. For more information see the see the New Policies for Transfer

Student Applicants website for L&S: https://ls.berkeley.edu/prospective-students/new-policies-transfer-student-applicants


By the end of the spring term preceding fall enrollment at Berkeley, you must complete: 

The 7-course pattern (as found in the UC Transfer Admission Eligibility Courses Menu in ASSIST):

  • Two transferable courses in English composition;
  • One transferable course in mathematical concepts and quantitative reasoning;
  • Four transferable college courses chosen from at least two of the following subject areas:
  • arts and humanities
  • social and behavioral sciences
  • physical and biological sciences
